required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Rasagiline in the Treatment of Persistent Negative Symptoms of Schizophrenia
clinical_study.official_title: Rasagiline in the Treatment of Persistent Negative Symptoms of Schizophrenia

brief_summary.textblock: This is a study of a new medication for the treatment of cognitive impairments (thinking difficulties) and negative symptoms in people with schizophrenia. The new medication is rasagiline. Rasagiline is a drug which has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of Parkinson's disease. It is used to treat cognitive problems.

detailed_description.textblock: The study will consist of two phases: a 4-week continued stability phase (lead-in phase) and a 12-week double-blind treatment phase. In the lead-in phase, subjects receiving antipsychotic medication, who manifest moderate to severe and persistent negative symptoms, will remain on their maintenance regimen for at least four weeks. The treatment phase will be a 12-week, parallel groups, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive rasagiline (1 mg/day), a selective MAO-B oxidase inhibitor.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Every 4 weeks over a 12 week period
primary_outcome.description: The Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms (SANS) rating scale was used to assess the negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Scores on the subscales are combined (summed) to compute a total score. There are a total of 17 subscales. Each subscale ranges from 0="Not at all" to 5="Severe". Every 4 weeks the summed subscale scores provide a total score for that week (0-85). Higher scores indicate more severe negative symptoms.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Testing - Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS) Total Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: The RBANS is a brief, individually administered test designed to evaluate neuropsychological status of adults, ages 20-89. The 12 subtests measure attention, language, visuospatial/constructional abilities, and immediate and delayed memory. The raw scores from the subtests are scaled together to create index scores, and these are summed for conversion to a total scale score. Higher score equals a better outcome. The total index score range for the RBANS is 40-160.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: The N-Back task is a sequential letter working memory task. D-prime was used to measure accuracy on the 0-back, 1-back, and 2-back conditions. D-prime scores range from 0 to 8.6. Higher scores are better. As memory load increases from 0 to 1, from 1 to 2, D-prime scores are expected to be lower.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: To assess reward learning, participants used performance feedback to choose the most frequently rewarded item in each of three pairs of stimuli (one pair had reward probabilities: 80% vs 20%; one pair had reward probabilities of 70% vs 30%; one pair had the probabilities of 60% vs 40 %) (PL; Frank et al, 2004). A total of 240 trials were administered so each pair was seen 80 times. Higher scores represent more frequent choices of the optimal stimulus in each pair. The frequencies with which participants repeated an item choice that was rewarded on the previous presentation (win-stay) is also presented as a percentage. Similarly, the lose-shift score is the percentage of times that participants changed their choice for unrewarded items (lose-shift). The win-stay score serves as a measure of the impact of positive feedback on subsequent choices while the lost-shift score serves as a measure of the impact of negative feedback on subsequent choices.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: The monetary choice questionnaire for hypothetical monetary rewards was used to assess delayed discounting (Kirby et al, 1999). The measure includes 27 items in which participants choose between a smaller, immediate reward (SIR) and a larger, delayed reward (LDR). There are three LDR sizes: small ($25-35), medium ($50-60) and large ($75-85). By examining the pattern of choices that participants make across the set of 27 items it is possible to calculate their delay discounting rate, termed K. The discount rate determines the steepness of the reduction in the present value of a reward with increases in the delay to the possible receipt of that reward. Thus, higher values in K represent greater discounting of the value of future rewards. With this measure K values can range between a low of 0.00016 to a high of 0.25. Higher K values have been linked to measures of impulsivity. Shown in the table are the K values observed when the future rewards were small, medium, or large.

secondary_outcome.description: The Simpson Angus Scale (SAS; Simpson and Angus, 1970) was used to assess extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS). The assessment consists of 11 items, each rating the severity of potential symptoms of movement disorders. Total scores are calculated by summing the scores of each of the 11 items for a potential total score of 0-44, with higher scores indicating more severe EPS.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and every two weeks throughout the double-blind phase of the study, for up to 12 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: The Barnes Akathisia Scale (BAS; Barnes, 1989) was used to assess akathisia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom. The global clinical assessment of akathisia score is rated on a scale from 0=Absent to 5=Severe Akathisia.

The Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) positive symptom item total score was used to assess positive symptom change. The BPRS positive symptom items are: conceptual disorganization, hallucinatory behavior, unusual thought content, and suspiciousness. The total score is calculated by adding the scores for each item. Each scale ranges from "1=Not Present" to "7=Very Severe". The minimum score is 4 and the maximum score is 28. A higher score indicates a more severe positive symptom rating.

The Calgary Depression Scale (CDS; Addington et al, 1997) total score was used to assess depressive symptoms over the course of the study. Total scores were calculated by summing the scores of each of the 9 items. Total scores can range from 0-27, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms.
The Clinical Global Impression (CGI) severity of illness item was used to assess global changes. Scores on this item range from 1="Normal, not at all ill" to 7="Among the most extremely ill".

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Exhibiting Side Effects
secondary_outcome.description: The Side Effect Checklist (SEC) was used to assess side effects. The SEC is comprised of 22 common side effects, which are rated on a 1 (none)-4 (severe) scale. Side effects are determined to be clinically significant if there is a two or more point increase in severity from baseline, or any side effect that receives a severity rating of "4" (severe) at any point in the treatment phase of the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects will meet DSM-IV criteria for schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
- Current treatment with one or more second generation antipsychotics, except ziprasidone
- On same second generation antipsychotic(s)for at least 56 days
- On same dose of second generation antipsychotic(s)for at least 30 days
- 22-item SANS: Total score (i.e.all items minus global items and poverty of content of speech)greater than 20 or global Rating of Affective Flattening greater than or equal to 3 or global Rating of alogia greater than or equal to 3
- BPRS: Sum of the four positive symptom items less than or equal to 16 (items 4,11,12,15)
- BPRS: Sum of the four Anxiety/Depression Factor items less than or equal to 14 (items 1,2,5,9)
- Simpson-Angus Scale: Total score less than or equal to 8
Exclusion Criteria:
- DSM-IV Major Depressive Disorder within last 6 months
- Current treatment with ziprasidone
- DSM-IV diagnosis of alcohol or substance dependence within the last 6 months
- DSM-IV criteria for alcohol or substance abuse within the last month
- evidence of illicit substance use, as identified with urine toxicology screen
- History of an organic brain disorder, mental retardation,epilepsy, or a medical condition, whose pathology or treatment could alter the presentation or treatment of schizophrenia or significantly increase the risk associated with the proposed treatment protocol. See those listed below
- Uncontrolled hypertension defined as BP exceeding 145/90 on 3 consecutive readings despite adequate treatment, pheochromocytoma, melanoma, hepatic insufficiency
- Pregnancy or lactation in females
- Pheochromocytoma
- Melanoma
- Hepatic insufficiency

responsible_party.investigator_title: Chief, Maryland Psychiatric Research Center, Outpatient Research Program

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited between May 2007-October 2011 from mental health clinics throughout the community.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were excluded before assignment to treatment groups if they met any of the exclusion criteria, if they became clinically unstable, or they decided that the demands of the study were too great. 84 participants were enrolled into active participation; 57 started study treatment.

outcome.title: Change in Negative Symptoms
outcome.description: The Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms (SANS) rating scale was used to assess the negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Scores on the subscales are combined (summed) to compute a total score. There are a total of 17 subscales. Each subscale ranges from 0="Not at all" to 5="Severe". Every 4 weeks the summed subscale scores provide a total score for that week (0-85). Higher scores indicate more severe negative symptoms.
outcome.time_frame: Every 4 weeks over a 12 week period
outcome.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

measure.title: Change in Negative Symptoms
measure.description: The Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms (SANS) rating scale was used to assess the negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Scores on the subscales are combined (summed) to compute a total score. There are a total of 17 subscales. Each subscale ranges from 0="Not at all" to 5="Severe". Every 4 weeks the summed subscale scores provide a total score for that week (0-85). Higher scores indicate more severe negative symptoms.
measure.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

outcome.title: Cognitive Testing - Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS) Total Score
outcome.description: The RBANS is a brief, individually administered test designed to evaluate neuropsychological status of adults, ages 20-89. The 12 subtests measure attention, language, visuospatial/constructional abilities, and immediate and delayed memory. The raw scores from the subtests are scaled together to create index scores, and these are summed for conversion to a total scale score. Higher score equals a better outcome. The total index score range for the RBANS is 40-160.
outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
outcome.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

measure.title: Cognitive Testing - Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS) Total Score
measure.description: The RBANS is a brief, individually administered test designed to evaluate neuropsychological status of adults, ages 20-89. The 12 subtests measure attention, language, visuospatial/constructional abilities, and immediate and delayed memory. The raw scores from the subtests are scaled together to create index scores, and these are summed for conversion to a total scale score. Higher score equals a better outcome. The total index score range for the RBANS is 40-160.
measure.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

outcome.title: Cognitive Testing - N-Back Neurocognitive Task
outcome.description: The N-Back task is a sequential letter working memory task. D-prime was used to measure accuracy on the 0-back, 1-back, and 2-back conditions. D-prime scores range from 0 to 8.6. Higher scores are better. As memory load increases from 0 to 1, from 1 to 2, D-prime scores are expected to be lower.
outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
outcome.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

measure.title: Cognitive Testing - N-Back Neurocognitive Task
measure.description: The N-Back task is a sequential letter working memory task. D-prime was used to measure accuracy on the 0-back, 1-back, and 2-back conditions. D-prime scores range from 0 to 8.6. Higher scores are better. As memory load increases from 0 to 1, from 1 to 2, D-prime scores are expected to be lower.
measure.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

outcome.title: Cognitive Testing - Probabilistic Learning Task
outcome.description: To assess reward learning, participants used performance feedback to choose the most frequently rewarded item in each of three pairs of stimuli (one pair had reward probabilities: 80% vs 20%; one pair had reward probabilities of 70% vs 30%; one pair had the probabilities of 60% vs 40 %) (PL; Frank et al, 2004). A total of 240 trials were administered so each pair was seen 80 times. Higher scores represent more frequent choices of the optimal stimulus in each pair. The frequencies with which participants repeated an item choice that was rewarded on the previous presentation (win-stay) is also presented as a percentage. Similarly, the lose-shift score is the percentage of times that participants changed their choice for unrewarded items (lose-shift). The win-stay score serves as a measure of the impact of positive feedback on subsequent choices while the lost-shift score serves as a measure of the impact of negative feedback on subsequent choices.
outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
outcome.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points. Results for lose shifts are calculated for 24 Rasagiline and 22 Placebo participants, due to missing data created by participants who had zero losses (and hence no need to shift) during both the 3rd and 4th blocks of trials.

measure.title: Cognitive Testing - Probabilistic Learning Task
measure.description: To assess reward learning, participants used performance feedback to choose the most frequently rewarded item in each of three pairs of stimuli (one pair had reward probabilities: 80% vs 20%; one pair had reward probabilities of 70% vs 30%; one pair had the probabilities of 60% vs 40 %) (PL; Frank et al, 2004). A total of 240 trials were administered so each pair was seen 80 times. Higher scores represent more frequent choices of the optimal stimulus in each pair. The frequencies with which participants repeated an item choice that was rewarded on the previous presentation (win-stay) is also presented as a percentage. Similarly, the lose-shift score is the percentage of times that participants changed their choice for unrewarded items (lose-shift). The win-stay score serves as a measure of the impact of positive feedback on subsequent choices while the lost-shift score serves as a measure of the impact of negative feedback on subsequent choices.
measure.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points. Results for lose shifts are calculated for 24 Rasagiline and 22 Placebo participants, due to missing data created by participants who had zero losses (and hence no need to shift) during both the 3rd and 4th blocks of trials.

outcome.title: Cognitive Testing - Delayed Discounting
outcome.description: The monetary choice questionnaire for hypothetical monetary rewards was used to assess delayed discounting (Kirby et al, 1999). The measure includes 27 items in which participants choose between a smaller, immediate reward (SIR) and a larger, delayed reward (LDR). There are three LDR sizes: small ($25-35), medium ($50-60) and large ($75-85). By examining the pattern of choices that participants make across the set of 27 items it is possible to calculate their delay discounting rate, termed K. The discount rate determines the steepness of the reduction in the present value of a reward with increases in the delay to the possible receipt of that reward. Thus, higher values in K represent greater discounting of the value of future rewards. With this measure K values can range between a low of 0.00016 to a high of 0.25. Higher K values have been linked to measures of impulsivity. Shown in the table are the K values observed when the future rewards were small, medium, or large.
outcome.time_frame: Beginning of treatment phase (week 0) and end of treatment phase (week 12)
outcome.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

measure.title: Cognitive Testing - Delayed Discounting
measure.description: The monetary choice questionnaire for hypothetical monetary rewards was used to assess delayed discounting (Kirby et al, 1999). The measure includes 27 items in which participants choose between a smaller, immediate reward (SIR) and a larger, delayed reward (LDR). There are three LDR sizes: small ($25-35), medium ($50-60) and large ($75-85). By examining the pattern of choices that participants make across the set of 27 items it is possible to calculate their delay discounting rate, termed K. The discount rate determines the steepness of the reduction in the present value of a reward with increases in the delay to the possible receipt of that reward. Thus, higher values in K represent greater discounting of the value of future rewards. With this measure K values can range between a low of 0.00016 to a high of 0.25. Higher K values have been linked to measures of impulsivity. Shown in the table are the K values observed when the future rewards were small, medium, or large.
measure.population: Subjects completing the cognitive testing at both time points.

outcome.title: Extrapyramidal Symptoms
outcome.description: The Simpson Angus Scale (SAS; Simpson and Angus, 1970) was used to assess extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS). The assessment consists of 11 items, each rating the severity of potential symptoms of movement disorders. Total scores are calculated by summing the scores of each of the 11 items for a potential total score of 0-44, with higher scores indicating more severe EPS.
outcome.population: SAS scores were collected at baseline on 28 Rasagiline and 29 Placebo patients. End of study scores were collected on 27 Rasagiline and 27 Placebo patients, including 5 patients who withdrew before Week 12 (1 Rasagiline patient at Week 4, 1 Placebo participant each at Weeks 3 and 6, and two Placebo participants at Week 8).

measure.title: Extrapyramidal Symptoms
measure.description: The Simpson Angus Scale (SAS; Simpson and Angus, 1970) was used to assess extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS). The assessment consists of 11 items, each rating the severity of potential symptoms of movement disorders. Total scores are calculated by summing the scores of each of the 11 items for a potential total score of 0-44, with higher scores indicating more severe EPS.
measure.population: SAS scores were collected at baseline on 28 Rasagiline and 29 Placebo patients. End of study scores were collected on 27 Rasagiline and 27 Placebo patients, including 5 patients who withdrew before Week 12 (1 Rasagiline patient at Week 4, 1 Placebo participant each at Weeks 3 and 6, and two Placebo participants at Week 8).

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Akathisia
outcome.description: The Barnes Akathisia Scale (BAS; Barnes, 1989) was used to assess akathisia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom. The global clinical assessment of akathisia score is rated on a scale from 0=Absent to 5=Severe Akathisia.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and every two weeks throughout the double-blind phase of the study, for up to 12 weeks.
outcome.population: Barnes Akathisia Scales at baseline and end of study were collected for 26 participants each in the rasagiline and placebo groups. End of study ratings were collected at week 12, except for 4 placebo participants (1 participant each at weeks 3 and 6, and two at week 8).

measure.title: Number of Participants With Akathisia
measure.description: The Barnes Akathisia Scale (BAS; Barnes, 1989) was used to assess akathisia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom. The global clinical assessment of akathisia score is rated on a scale from 0=Absent to 5=Severe Akathisia.
measure.population: Barnes Akathisia Scales at baseline and end of study were collected for 26 participants each in the rasagiline and placebo groups. End of study ratings were collected at week 12, except for 4 placebo participants (1 participant each at weeks 3 and 6, and two at week 8).

outcome.title: Change in Persistent Positive Symptoms
outcome.description: The Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) positive symptom item total score was used to assess positive symptom change. The BPRS positive symptom items are: conceptual disorganization, hallucinatory behavior, unusual thought content, and suspiciousness. The total score is calculated by adding the scores for each item. Each scale ranges from "1=Not Present" to "7=Very Severe". The minimum score is 4 and the maximum score is 28. A higher score indicates a more severe positive symptom rating.
outcome.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

measure.title: Change in Persistent Positive Symptoms
measure.description: The Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) positive symptom item total score was used to assess positive symptom change. The BPRS positive symptom items are: conceptual disorganization, hallucinatory behavior, unusual thought content, and suspiciousness. The total score is calculated by adding the scores for each item. Each scale ranges from "1=Not Present" to "7=Very Severe". The minimum score is 4 and the maximum score is 28. A higher score indicates a more severe positive symptom rating.
measure.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

outcome.title: Depressive Symptoms
outcome.description: The Calgary Depression Scale (CDS; Addington et al, 1997) total score was used to assess depressive symptoms over the course of the study. Total scores were calculated by summing the scores of each of the 9 items. Total scores can range from 0-27, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms.
outcome.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

measure.title: Depressive Symptoms
measure.description: The Calgary Depression Scale (CDS; Addington et al, 1997) total score was used to assess depressive symptoms over the course of the study. Total scores were calculated by summing the scores of each of the 9 items. Total scores can range from 0-27, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms.
measure.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

outcome.title: Global Change in Illness Severity
outcome.description: The Clinical Global Impression (CGI) severity of illness item was used to assess global changes. Scores on this item range from 1="Normal, not at all ill" to 7="Among the most extremely ill".
outcome.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

measure.title: Global Change in Illness Severity
measure.description: The Clinical Global Impression (CGI) severity of illness item was used to assess global changes. Scores on this item range from 1="Normal, not at all ill" to 7="Among the most extremely ill".
measure.population: Number of participants available for symptom efficacy analyses.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Exhibiting Side Effects
outcome.description: The Side Effect Checklist (SEC) was used to assess side effects. The SEC is comprised of 22 common side effects, which are rated on a 1 (none)-4 (severe) scale. Side effects are determined to be clinically significant if there is a two or more point increase in severity from baseline, or any side effect that receives a severity rating of "4" (severe) at any point in the treatment phase of the study.
outcome.population: One placebo patient for whom a baseline side effects checklist was excluded from these analyses.

measure.title: Number of Participants Exhibiting Side Effects
measure.description: The Side Effect Checklist (SEC) was used to assess side effects. The SEC is comprised of 22 common side effects, which are rated on a 1 (none)-4 (severe) scale. Side effects are determined to be clinically significant if there is a two or more point increase in severity from baseline, or any side effect that receives a severity rating of "4" (severe) at any point in the treatment phase of the study.
measure.population: One placebo patient for whom a baseline side effects checklist was excluded from these analyses.

reported_events.time_frame: During the 12-week Treatment Phase of the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
